(Private)
[Variable Math]

Collaboration diagram for (Private):

Detailed Description

Description:

Helper functions to perform built-in operations on data arrays.

  • _fc_negateInts()
  • _fc_negateDoubles()
  • _fc_addInts()
  • _fc_subtractInts()
  • _fc_multiplyInts()
  • _fc_divideInts()
  • _fc_addDoubles()
  • _fc_subtractDoubles()
  • _fc_multiplyDoubles()
  • _fc_divideDoubles()

The motivation for using these functions (as opposed to using fc_varUnaryFunction() and similar functions) are: 1) it is more efficient to do built-in operation over entire array than to embed the operation in a function that is called repeatedly; and 2) we are also using them help to retain type when appropriate (i.e. if you add two ints, you get an int).

All of the built-in helper functions assume that the calling program has allocated room for the results.

The binary built-in helper functions operate on interleaved data arrays--that is if you have numData data points and numComp components, the jth component of the ith data point is found by data[i*numComp+j]. All data arrays are assume to have the same number of components. If they also have the same number of data points, the operation is performed for each data value. A special case is allowed for when one of the data arrays has just one data point. In that case, that single data point is used for all data points of the other array.

FC_ReturnCode _fc_binaryOperatorCore ( int  numComp,
int  numData1,
void *  data1,
FC_DataType  datatype1,
char *  operation,
int  numData2,
void *  data2,
FC_DataType  datatype2,
FC_Variable  origVar,
char *  new_var_name,
FC_Variable *  new_var 
)

Performs built-in binary operation on two data arrays.

Description:

This is the core of fc_varOperatorVar(), fc_varOperatorConst(), and fc_constOperatorVar().

Modifications:

  • 11/10/03 WSK, created.
Parameters:
numComp  input - number of components in both data arrays
numData1  input - number of data points in data 1
data1  input - data array 1
datatype1  input - type of data 1
operation  input - operation string
numData2  input - number of data points in data 2
data2  input - data array 2
datatype2  input - type of data 2
origVar  input - reference var
new_var_name  input - name for the new variable
new_var  output - the new variable

void _fc_decomposeVector ( int  dim_in,
double *  inputVector,
int  dim_ref,
double *  referenceVector,
double *  normalComponent,
double *  tangentComponent 
)

Decompose a vector into normal and tangent components respective to a reference vector.

Description:

Most common usage will be to decompose a force on a surface into a component in the direction of the surface normal, and a component tangential to the surface.

Note, an infinite number of vectors are tangent to the reference vector. The calculated tangential component will be in the plane defined by the input vector and the reference vector. (Perhaps we should also calculate and return this?)

Note, the dimensions of the input and reference vector do not have to be equal. The extra dimensions are assumed to have component values of zero. (In fact, one of the vectors could be a scalar. This would correspond to a vector aligned with the X axis).

Modifications:

  • 2003-SEP-05 W Koegler Created by moving code from fc_decomposeVector
  • 11/01/04 WSK Moved from geom to varmath
Parameters:
dim_in  input - the number of components in the input vector
inputVector  input - the vector to be decomposed
dim_ref  input - the number of components in the reference vector
referenceVector  input - the components of the reference vector
normalComponent  output - the normal component
tangentComponent  output - the tangent component

Definition at line 4235 of file varmath.c.

References FC_DBL_EQUIV, fc_printfLogMessage, and FC_VALUE_EQUIV.

Referenced by fc_createNormalTangentVariables(), fc_createNormalTangentVariables2(), and fc_evalPrestoSpotWeld().

04242   {
04243   int i;
04244   int dim_min;
04245   double inMagnitude_sq;            // squared magnitude of input vector (^2)
04246   double refMagnitude;              // magnitude of reference vector
04247   double normalizedRefVec[dim_ref]; // normalized reference vector
04248   double* refVector_p;              // pointer to the reference vector
04249   double normal, tangent;
04250   
04251   // default output values  
04252   *normalComponent = 0.;
04253   *tangentComponent = 0.;
04254   
04255   // log message
04256   fc_printfLogMessage("Decomposing vector.");  
04257   
04258   // calculate magnitudes of the vectors & return if they are zero
04259   inMagnitude_sq = 0;
04260   for (i = 0; i < dim_in; i++)
04261     inMagnitude_sq += inputVector[i]*inputVector[i];
04262   if (sqrt(inMagnitude_sq) < DBL_MIN)
04263     return;
04264   refMagnitude = 0;
04265   for (i = 0; i < dim_ref; i++)
04266     refMagnitude += referenceVector[i]*referenceVector[i];
04267   refMagnitude = sqrt(refMagnitude);
04268   if (refMagnitude < DBL_MIN)
04269     return;
04270   
04271   // if necessary, normalize the reference vector
04272   if (!FC_DBL_EQUIV(refMagnitude, 1.)) {
04273     for (i = 0; i < dim_ref; i++)
04274       normalizedRefVec[i] = referenceVector[i]/refMagnitude;
04275     refVector_p = normalizedRefVec;
04276   }
04277   else
04278     refVector_p = referenceVector;
04279   
04280   // calculate Normal Component, use smaller of dims
04281   // Fn = F dot N = SUM(fi*ni)   
04282   dim_min = dim_in < dim_ref ? dim_in : dim_ref;
04283   normal = 0;
04284   for (i = 0; i < dim_min; i++)
04285     normal += inputVector[i]*refVector_p[i];
04286   
04287   // calculate tangent component, use
04288   // Ft = SQRT(|F|^2 - Fn^2) = SQRT( SUM(fi^2) - Fn^2 )
04289   tangent = inMagnitude_sq - normal*normal;
04290   if (FC_VALUE_EQUIV(inMagnitude_sq, normal*normal, 4*DBL_EPSILON, DBL_MIN))
04291     tangent = 0.;
04292   else
04293     tangent = sqrt(tangent);
04294   
04295   *normalComponent = normal;
04296   *tangentComponent = tangent;
04297 }

03270     for (i = 0; i < numDataPoint2; i++)
03271       for (j = 0; j < numComp; j++)
03272      resultData[i*numComp+j] = data1[j] * data2[i*numComp+j];
03273   }
03274   else if (numDataPoint2 == 1) { // 2nd entry is a constant
03275     for (i = 0; i < numDataPoint1; i++)
03276       for (j = 0; j < numComp; j++)
03277      resultData[i*numComp+j] = data1[i*numComp+j] * data2[j]; 
03278   }
03279   else
03280     return FC_ERROR;
03281 
03282   return FC_SUCCESS;
03283 }

)

Helper function to do multiplication of int data arrays.

See (Private).

Modifications:

  • 01/29/04 R.McCoy Created.
  • 02/20/04 changed to enable operations with "constant" arrays.
  • 11/09/04 WSK, changed to allow operations with constants in either position, and no longer allocates memory.
